messageBody:
Hi.

About JUnit addon's "_ignore" feature. NUnit has an attribute called
[Ignore(string mesg)] that you can attach to a test case. This essentially
works the same as the _ignore name change. The progress bar turns yellow and
you get all the statistics.

What's nice about C# in this regard is you can create your own attributes (they
are just classes that can be reflected on at runtime,) to do various things. Is
there a way to approach this in Java/JUnit with XDoclet, AspectJ or some other
method?

Going further, I'd like see a modification of TestRunner that externalizes the
runnable states of test cases for a given fixture. I see a repeated pattern of
usage with JUnit: after a refactoring, some test or tests break. You want to
focus on those, either by fixing them or the code. Eliminating the rest of the
cases while narrowly focusing on a few can be time consuming if there are many.

It would be handy to have a GUI or file to indicate some or all of the tests to
be ignored. In the case of the file (for command line/Ant usage,) a pattern
similar to the TCP wrappers accept or deny files. If a file called junit.ignore
exists, it is read for the cases to ignore. A special case called ALLCASES
would ignore the entire named fixture. After that, a section for cases to run.
These would be the short list of cases to run while the others are ignored.

This file could act as the serialized state of the GUI component which would
have a bunch of check boxes and buttons to Ignore ALL, Run All. There could
also be a nested element in Ant's JUnit task to accomplish this. (Ant does have
if/unless "property" but that is still per test.)

Does anybody else think this is a good idea?

Ed
